node.title: After detecting the Omnicron variant, South Africa feels ‘punished’ by global travel bans.
node.alt: A lab at the Nelson Mandela School of Medicine in Durban. South African scientists alerted global health authorities on Thursday to a new variant.
node.description: Hours after South African scientists announced the existence of a troublesome new variant, Britain banned travelers from southern Africa. The United States and other nations quickly followed suit.
node.content: ["JOHANNESBURG \u2014 As the United States and European countries close their borders over fears over the recently detected coronavirus variant, many South Africans say they feel as if they are being \u201cpunished\u201d for alerting global health authorities.", "Hours after South African scientists announced the existence of a new variant that they said displayed \u201ca big jump in evolution,\u201d Britain banned travelers from southern African nations. Other European nations and the United States quickly followed suit.", "\u201cI do apologize that people took a very radical decision,\u201d said Tulio de Oliveira, director of the KwaZulu-Natal Research and Innovation Sequencing Platform and the scientist who announced the new variant on Thursday.", "Fresh from a virtual meeting with global health leaders, including Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, President Biden\u2019s top medical adviser on the coronavirus, Mr. Oliveira told journalists he believed that international solidarity would be in favor of South Africa\u2019s decision to publicize its findings.", "The variant, dubbed Omicron by the World Health Organization, has been detected in 22 patients in South Africa. In neighboring Botswana, four cases of the new variant were found. The government announced that the four cases were all foreign diplomats who had since left, and that contact tracing was continuing.", "The economies of South Africa and Botswana are reliant on tourists from the United States, Europe and China. South Africa\u2019s tourism minister, Lindiwe Sisulu, described the temporary travel bans as \u201cdevastating.\u201d Earlier this year, South African diplomats and scientists lobbied the British government to lift a previous ban that had already crippled tourism.", "\u201cWe had been on the British red list and we worked our way out of it and with no notification we find ourselves back on the red list,\u201d Ms. Sisulu told a national television station.", "\u201cPerhaps our scientists\u2019 ability to trace some of these variants has been our biggest weakness,\u201d Ms. Sisulu said. \u201cWe\u2019re finding ourselves punished for the work that we do.\u201d", "Health officials in Africa suggested that increased screening at points of entry, or even longer quarantine periods, would have been a better alternative.", "\u201cThis will just discourage different countries for sharing information which might be very important for global public health,\u201d said Thierno Balde, incident manager for the Covid-19 emergency response for the World Health Organization\u2019s regional office in Africa.", "South Africa\u2019s transparency was criticized by some local officials and businesspeople. Geordin Hill-Lewis, the mayor of Cape Town, said South African officials should have consulted their \u201ctravel partners\u201d before making the announcement.", "In January 2020, before global travel restrictions over the coronavirus pandemic, 93,315 international tourists arrived at Cape Town International airport, according to Statistics South Africa. By May 2021, that number had dropped to 4,821.", "After the travel restrictions imposed after the highly transmissible Delta variant, Mr. Hill-Lewis said he believed that South African authorities should have expected the restrictions.", "\u201cThat should have been foreseen and some heavy diplomacy put into action,\u201d he said.", "But Craig Lucke, a Cape Town-based guide who operates tours in Namibia, Botswana and South Africa called the countries\u2019 actions \u201ca total shocker.\u201d "]
